Author: mynameishere
Content:
Lots of people short, lots of people long. Nothing special about it. I made a pile of money on Countrywide a few days ago. Am I a genius?

The only distinction of a fund manager is that they slimed their way into using other people's money.

Author: edw519
Content:
Yes, you are an outsider. I haven't seen what you describe as "contemporary American business culture" in at least 10 years.

As far as "stepping on the limits of what is appropriate, just to see how people react" goes, fine. Whatever turns you on. Just don't be surprised when the other person's reaction costs you. It can happen (and probably will).

Personally, I'd rather spend my energy doing great work and succeeding, whatever it takes.

Author: ks
Content: The license should cover patents. If a company adds to the code using patented algorithms, they could perhaps block further development since nobody could use the code? I'm not a lawyer, so perhaps it's not a problem anyway.

Author: akkartik
Content:
There's a reason companies can do this: most people don't bother keeping up on what they're worth in the open market. Inertia's a bitch. Especially after a few years working.

Another way to say that: people's worths tend towards what they get paid. Especially if that's all they get out of work.

Author: mrtron
Title: Macbook Air - new business laptop?
Content:
Apple just announced their Macbook Air.

MacBook Air is 0.16" to 0.76". The thickest part of the MacBook Air is thinner than the thinnest part of the Sony. It fits inside a envelope.

It is insanely tiny, it seems like the perfect laptop for business meetings and traveling.

Thoughts?

Author: mrtron
Content: Many companies are penny wise and dollar stupid.

Author: mechanical_fish
Content:
Well, of course you can't find $100/hr being offered on a random job board. Nobody is crazy enough to hire an unknown quantity off the street at those rates, no matter what the demand is. See Spolsky, Joel: http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/FindingGreatDeveloper...

The people who are working for $100+/hr are getting those jobs directly from the companies that auditioned them at $40-$80 per hour, or from friends-of-friends of the managers at those companies.
